awd_titl_txt: REU SITE: IDEA Incubator for Porous Materials: Integrating Discovery, Engineering and Art
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site will create an IDEA Incubator at the University of Kansas (KU) by integrating discovery, engineering and art. The primary goal is to engage a diverse cohort of REU students in a variety of experiences, both in and out of the laboratory, that will nurture creativity, communication and other important skills for the 21st Century workforce. Emphasizing innovative thinking in particular is essential since the future competitiveness of the U.S. in the global economy depends on innovators to create products and processes of value to society. REU students will grow as researchers by engaging in team-based learning on projects focused on porous materials, which have a wide-variety of biomedical and chemical applications. With a host of variables that can be altered and tested, this field of research is ideal for tinkering and ripe for discovery and innovation. Training activities will also help students build a solid understanding of size and scale, two concepts that tend to be under-developed but essential for scientific literacy and discovery. 

During the 10-week summer program, this REU Site offers opportunities for undergraduate students to engage in research on topics relating to porous materials that range from fundamental to applied. For example, participants will be immersed in how to design stable delivery systems for vaccines, adsorbents for chemical separations, nanofiber scaffolds for tissue engineering, and catalysts for hydrogen generation and biomass conversion.  In addition, students will gain hands-on experience with state-of-the-art biophysical and analytical techniques for characterizing porous materials and how these materials interact with other molecules. The REU students? will be supported in the laboratory by specially trained faculty and graduate student mentors. The students will also engage in tours of nearby companies, boredom-busting unseminars, interactive workshops, social mixers and team-building activities. The extensive partnerships with nine companies and an art museum, as well as active-learning classrooms and high-tech labs make this REU Site uniquely positioned to create a successful and inclusive learning experience for all students. Furthermore, synergistic benefits will arise from partnering with a KU Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) Site, leading to broader impacts for high school level educators and students.

This project is jointly funded by the Directorate for Engineering (ENG), Division of Engineering Education and Centers (EEC) and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF REU Site program called “IDEA Incubator for Porous Materials: Integrating Discovery, Engineering, and Art” (NSF REU 1852308) and NSF REU supplement (NSF Award 2022120) supported 30 students during the summers of 2019-2022 with Prof. Mark Shiflett as PI, Dr. Claudia Bode as co-PI, and Dr. Felipe Anaya as program director (summer 2022). Each summer, 10 undergraduates were supported with NSF funds and 3-7 University of Kansas students were supported with departmental funds. Participants received a $5,000 stipend, travel reimbursement, and room and board. A No Cost Extension (NCE) provided funding for summer 2022 (summer 2020 was postponed to COVID).

The primary objectives were to: (1) engage undergraduate students in cutting-edge research projects in porous material design, synthesis, and characterization for biomedical and chemical engineering applications; (2) help undergraduates develop a solid understanding of size and scale; (3) nurture innovative thinking; and (4) provide an inclusive and safe learning environment that supports and appreciates diversity, aimed at preparing undergraduates for future careers in science and engineering.

REU participants worked in teams with 10 faculty mentors and in many cases alongside a high school teacher sponsored by NSF-RET programs (e.g., “RET: Exploring Career Opportunities through Water-Themed Engineering Research (EcoWater)” and “RET: Inquiry Driven Engineering Activities using Bioengineering Examples (IDEA-BioE)”. The interface between REU students and the application of porous materials with RET teachers learning the latest in environmental and bioengineering provided unique cross-training opportunities for the teachers to develop education modules. REU summer activities included: training related to research, ethics and lab safety, green chemistry workshops, tours of labs, museums, and industrial facilities, teambuilding challenge course, a “talent show”, and social events. Each student also presented a professional presentation and a poster on their research at the end of the summer to the School of Engineering and Department of Chemistry faculty.

The 2019-2022 site grant received an average of 80 applications each year and supported 45 students total (2019 10/3, 2021 10/5, and 2022 10/7 REU/KU supported). These students came from the following private and public universities across the U.S.: U. South Carolina, U. Pittsburgh at Johnstown, U. North Dakota, U. Puerto Rico at Mayagüez Campus, Bethel College, Kansas State U., U. South Florida, U. Kansas, U. Oklahoma, U. Florida, Louisiana State U., North Carolina State U., College of St. Scholastica, U. New Hampshire, Georgia Inst. of Technology, U. Notre Dame. U. Colorado School of Mines, U. Maryland, Cornell U., Auburn U., Brigham Young U., Florida Inst. of Technology, Meredith College, U. South Dakota School of Mines, U. Houston, and Wichita State U.

Our current REU program (2019-2022) significantly improved the inclusion of women from 22% to 64% and our efforts to attract URMs improved from 7% to 22%. In addition, the current program had 10% first-generation students.

The NSF has renewed the REU program for three more years (Award 2243816, 2023 – 2025).

Research publications/presentations/awards: REU students were encouraged to be co-authors on research publications and conference presentations Over 30% of the participants were co-authors on 12 research publications and 33 conference presentations and several students also received awards.

Program Evaluation for 2019-2022 REU: Students generally regarded the experience favorably, indicating among other things that the experience demystified the concept of graduate research, making it apparent that it is something within their reach. Another primary benefit was to help encourage students to consider graduate education and careers in research. Impact on participants’ careers is as follows:

  • 22% of the students (10 total) went on to pursue advanced degrees (PhD, M.S., MD).
  • 10% of the students (5 total) became engineers for various companies across the country.
  • Of the remaining, 29 are finishing B.S. degrees and 1 student is undecided on a career path.

Exit surveys were given to students at the end of each summer to 1) to assess the mechanics of the program and 2) to evaluate the impact of the program on the participants thinking and planning. With regard to mechanics, there were several suggestions having to do with scheduling and requests for more lab tours. No major program problems were identified, and all of the students indicated that the program was valuable to them and that they would recommend it to other students at their institutions. Around 75% of the students indicated that the experience had strengthened their desire to go to graduate school, and they overwhelmingly indicated that having the opportunity for hands on experience has been of great value in defining or refining their interest in research. A key aspect of this program was the combination of art, design, and visualization with porous materials training. All participants felt this was a unique experience and a key attraction for why they applied to this program. Because of the strength of this learning experience, we plan to continue it for students in the current REU site.
